Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Biomedical Engineering in Simulations, Imaging and Modeling (BME-SIM)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
This program is supported by the Division of Engineering Education and Centers. The goal of the BME-Simulations, Imaging and Modeling (SIM) Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) is to provide a quality research experience to students, especially underrepresented minorities, in eastern North Carolina increasing awareness of and application to graduate school. At the end of the program students should have a better understanding of how to conduct research, increased awareness of graduate school, clarification and reinforcement of STEM career path, and greater identification as engineer/scientist. To achieve these program goals we plan to engage participants for longer than the 10 week summer research experience by collaborating with off-site mentors at our targeted institutions. To ensure a broad applicant pool, student recruitment will begin at our targeted institutions: Elizabeth City State University, Fayetteville State University, and North Carolina Central University, historically black institutions, and University of North Carolina-Pembroke, a public institution serving a large Native American population. National recruiting by listserv announcements and website information will supplement the targeted recruiting. Graduates of the program will gain a better understanding of graduate school and be competitive in the graduate school application process increasing diversity in the STEM pipeline.

The educational goals of the REU will be accomplished through a multidisciplinary approach using simulations, imaging, and modeling as a common thread. The popularity of computational research models has increased due to limited use of human subjects and animals. In addition, models can be used to test hypothetical situations or new devices. The introduction of subject specific modeling has allowed for detailed analysis using the subject's own parameters. Generally these parameters can be derived from non-invasive imaging techniques. Through the REU program students will be exposed to cutting edge research utilizing advanced computational models with applications in biomedical engineering.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
This program is supported by the Division of Engineering Education and Centers. The BME-Simulations, Imaging and Modeling (SIM) Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) will provide high quality research experiences to targeted students, specifically underrepresented minorities. Exposing underrepresented minorities to innovative research will increase their awareness about graduate school and ultimately increase the STEM graduate school pipe line. The proposed REU program will also strengthen their STEM career paths and increase student's identities as scientists or engineers. These research opportunities would generally not be available to the targeted student populations without this program. Due to the multidisciplinary nature of the faculty mentors, the proposed work will also encourage research collaboration among the faculty mentors and across academic departments on campus. Including off-site mentors in the recruitment process will facilitate collaboration between ECU and the targeted institutions increasing research opportunities.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
Quality undergraduate research experiences improve the educational experience and increase the likelihood of students pursuing graduate degrees in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math). However, many students do not have access to quality research opportunities at the home institution. This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) award supported training and development of 25 students.  The focus of the research projects was on the integration of imaging and modeling, giving students skills needed for competitive graduate school applications and in the STEM workforce.  While the highlight of the student experience was the research project, students also received valuable professional development training, and built mentoring relationships with REU faculty, home institution mentors, and the other REU students.  

Intellectual Merit

In addition to providing educational experiences, it was also the goal of this program to conduct impactful research and share these results with the scientific community. The research from this grant resulted in three peer-reviewed research articles, and 29 research conference presentations.  The large majority of the conference presentations were presented by the REU students. The results from these research projects has advanced the state of knowledge in several areas. For example: one project developed a scalable tibia model used to estimate bone stress, which can provide insight into at-risk running biomechanics for injuries.  Another student project demonstrated the feasibility of calculating wall shear stress in the pulmonary artery using phase-contrast magnetic resonance imaging (PC-MRI). These results could lead to future non-invasive diagnostic tools for monitoring pulmonary hypertension. Another project demonstrated the feasibility of using a custom approach to tracking images using infrared imaging. The results of this work could have implications for computer vision. Another example project published in Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering described an approach to determine subject specific muscle model parameters using a combination of ultrasound imaging and static optimization. These findings could impact a wide variety of future modeling studies.

In addition to research on biomechanics, simulations, imaging, and modeling, we also conducted research on the effectiveness of unique aspects of our research program. One of these studies examined benefits of our program theme and was published in The Journal of Biomechanical Engineering, and highlighted by being chosen as Editor’s Pick for 2017 and as Pick of the Week in July 2017 on an online biomechanics listserv community (Biomch-L).

Broader Impacts

Our program was successful at encouraging graduate school enrollment for our alumni. Twenty-two students who participated in the program have graduated from their undergraduate program thus far. Among the students who have graduated, 72.7% have enrolled in graduate programs, and 75% of these students are in STEM (Engineering, Physics, Biomedical Sciences). Most of these students are working in research areas directly related to the theme of the REU program (Biomechanics, Simulations, Imaging, or Modeling).  Our students who have graduated, but not enrolled in graduate school have gone on to successful industry careers, with 83.3% working in STEM fields or research. 

We used a unique strategy in our program recruitment, involving partnerships with several regional universities, to encourage diverse participation specifically targeting under-represented populations.  Many of our students are from populations that have traditionally been underrepresented in science and engineering. Forty percent of our participants were from underrepresented minorities and 56% were women.  Our program was also successful in encouraging participation among students from institutions with traditionally limited research opportunities. The large majority (92%) of our students came from institutions with limited research opportunities.

In addition to providing a diverse group of students with research experiences and successful graduate enrollment rates, we have disseminated best practices, and mentoring and recruitment strategies to the educational community through publications and presentations.
